content.text: Define the radian
an arrow, labelled V, showing the direction of the velocity of the modelling clay
an arrow, labelled A, showing the direction of the acceleration of the modelling clay
A circular metal disc spins horizontally about a vertical axis, as shown in Fig. 1.1
A piece of modelling clay is attached to the disc
For the instant when the piece of modelling clay is in the position shown, draw on Fig. 1.1:
Calculate the angular speed \(\omega\) of the disc
Calculate the acceleration \(a\) of the centre of gravity of the modelling clay
The metal disc in Fig. 1.1 has a radius of \(9.3 \text{cm}\)
The centre of gravity of the modelling clay is \(1.2 \text{cm}\) from the rim of the disc and moves with a speed of \(0.68 \text{m s}^{-1}\)
A second piece of modelling clay is attached to the disc in the position shown in Fig. 1.2
The second piece of modelling clay has a larger mass than the first piece
By placing **one** tick \((\checkmark)\) in each row, complete Table 1.1 to show how the quantities indicated compare for the two pieces of modelling clay

table.html:
quantityless for second piece than first piecesame for both piecesgreater for second piece than first piece
angular speed
linear speed
acceleration

content.text: With reference to thermal energy, state what is meant by two objects being in thermal equilibrium
Show that the temperature of the gas in X is \(234\,^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Determine the number \(N\) of molecules of the gas in Y. Explain your reasoning
The gas in X consists of molecules that each have a mass that is four times the mass of a molecule of the gas in Y
Explain how the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of the molecules in X compares with the r.m.s. speed of the molecules in Y
Two cylinders X and Y each contain a sample of an ideal gas. The samples are in thermal equilibrium with each other

X has a volume of \(0.0260 \text{m}^3\) and contains \(0.740 \text{mol}\) of gas at a pressure of \(1.20 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\). Y has a volume of \(0.0430 \text{m}^3\) and contains gas at a pressure of \(2.90 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\). Data for the two cylinders are shown in Fig. 2.1
State what is meant by the internal energy of a system
a gas is heated at constant volume so that its temperature increases
a wire is stretched within its elastic limit at constant temperature
With reference to molecular kinetic and potential energies, describe and explain how the internal energy of the system changes when:
Explain how Fig. 4.2 shows that the oscillations of the block are simple harmonic
the angular frequency \(\omega\) of the oscillations
the maximum speed \(\nu_{0}\) of the oscillations
the energy \(E\) of the oscillations
Deduce expressions, in terms of some or all of \(m, A\) and \(Y,\) for:
The period of the oscillations is 0.75 s and the value of \(3Y\) is \(1.8 \text{cm}\)
Determine an expression for \(x\) in terms of time \(t\), where \(x\) is in cm and \(t\) is in seconds
A block of mass \(m\) oscillates vertically on a spring, as shown in Fig. 4.1
The acceleration \(a\) of the block varies with displacement \(x\) from its equilibrium position, as shown in Fig. 4.2
The amplitude of the oscillations is \(3Y\) and the maximum acceleration is \(2A\)
Define electric potential at a point
Two isolated charged metal spheres X and Y are near to each other in a vacuum. The centres of the spheres are \(1.2 \text{m}\) apart, as shown in Fig. 5.1
Point P is on the line joining the centres of spheres X and Y and is at a variable distance x from the centre of X
Fig. 5.2 shows the variation with \(x\) of the total electric potential \(V\) due to the two spheres
A proton is held at rest on the line joining the centres of the spheres in **(b)** at the position where \(x = 0.60 \text{m}\)
The proton is released
Describe and explain, without calculation, the subsequent motion of the proton
Two capacitors X and Y are connected in series to a power supply of voltage \(V,\) as shown in Fig. 6.1
The capacitance of X is \(C_{\mathrm{X}}\) and the capacitance of Y is \(C_{\mathrm{Y}}\)
Derive an expression, in terms of \(C_{\mathrm{X}}\) and \(C_{\mathrm{Y}}\), for the combined capacitance \(C_{\mathrm{T}}\) of the capacitors in this circuit
Explain your reasoning
Show that the supply voltage \(V\) is 5.0 V
Calculate the total energy, in mJ, stored in the capacitors when \(C_{\mathrm{Q}}\) has its maximum value
total energy =   .........  mJ
On Fig. 6.2, sketch the variation of the total energy \(E\) stored in the capacitors with \(C_{\mathrm{Q}}\), as \(C_{\mathrm{Q}}\) varies from 0 to 400 \(\mu \mathrm{F}\)
Two capacitors P and Q are connected in parallel to a power supply of voltage \(V.\)

The capacitance of P is \(200 \mu \text{F}\). The capacitance \(C_{\text{Q}}\) of Q can be varied between 0 and \(400 \mu \text{F}\). When \(C_{\text{Q}} = 0\), the total energy stored in the capacitors is \(2.5 \text{mJ}\)
State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction
Calculate the maximum magnetic flux through one turn of the coil
Determine the maximum rate of change of magnetic flux linkage in the coil
maximum rate of change of flux linkage = ......................................... Wbs\(^{- 1}\)
State the maximum electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(V_0\) induced across the coil
On Fig. 7.3, sketch the variation of the e.m.f. \(V\) induced across the coil with \(t\) from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 6.0 \text{ms}\)
The variation of \(V\) with \(t\) can be described by
where \(A\) and \(B\) are constants
Determine the values of \(A\) and \(B\). Give units with your answers
Fig. 7.1 shows a coil at rest in a uniform magnetic field that is parallel to the axis of the coil
The coil is connected to a centre-zero voltmeter
The flux density \(B\) of the uniform magnetic field varies with time \(t\) as shown in Fig. 7.2
The coil consists of 340 turns, each of cross-sectional area \(3.2 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}^2\)
Explain how the positions of the lines in the emission spectrum seen by an observer on the Earth differ from the positions shown in Fig. 8.1
On Fig. 8.1, draw the three lines in possible positions in the spectrum seen by the observer
Calculate the energy of a photon of this radiation
photon energy =   .........  J
Determine the energy, in eV, of the energy level from which the electron transition originates to cause the emission of this radiation
energy level =   .........  eV
Determine the wavelength, in nm, of this radiation as detected by the observer on the Earth
wavelength =   .........  nm
The lines in Fig. 8.1 correspond to electron transitions down to the energy level \(-3.40 \text{eV}\). One of the lines represents emitted radiation of wavelength \(488 \text{nm}\)
A value for the Hubble constant is \(2.3 \times 10^{-18} \text{s}^{-1}\)
Determine the distance of the galaxy from the Earth
distance =   .........  m
Fig. 8.1 shows part of the emission spectrum of visible radiation emitted by hydrogen gas in a star in a distant galaxy
The galaxy is moving away from the Earth at a speed of \(6.2 \times 10^{6} \text{m s}^{-1}\)
State what is meant by the binding energy of a nucleus
the mass defect \(\Delta m\), in kg
the binding energy
binding energy =   .........  J
the binding energy per nucleon
binding energy per nucleon =   .........  J
Table 9.1 shows the masses of two sub-atomic particles and a polonium-212 ( \(^{212}_{84}\mathrm{Po})\) nucleus
For the polonium-212 nucleus, determine:
On Fig. 9.1, sketch the variation with nucleon number \(A\) of binding energy per nucleon for values of \(A\) from 1 to 250
On your line in Fig. 9.1, draw an X to show the approximate position of polonium-212
Polonium-212 is radioactive and undergoes alpha-decay
Suggest and explain, with reference to Fig. 9.1, why the alpha-decay of polonium-212 results in a release of energy
Describe how reflected ultrasound pulses may be used to obtain diagnostic information about internal structures
Define specific acoustic impedance of a medium
Table 10.1 shows some data for water and for glass
Determine the intensity reflection coefficient for ultrasound that is incident on a waterglass boundary
intensity reflection coefficient =   .........
